body.value: But it took time for society to get to our present understanding and Prohibition was part of that. Eg, the patent medicine era in the 19th century in which alcohol was commonly included; some even had opiates. Coca Cola first marketed as something of a cure all with an active ingredient of cocaine. From Ken Burn's documentary on prohibition, I recall that some variants of whiskey were even allowed with a prescription for "medicinal purposes" and those heavily exploited for recreational use.

Maybe one day pot will be similarly managed w/ analogies to the difference between beer, wine, and liquor. Even sub-variants like whiskey vs grain alcohol. Should we discover some strains are more like heroin then they can be made illegal. But the process of figuring that out will be messy with some collateral damage.

category: Political Controversies and Governance Challenges

title: Another post-election mailbag
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Yes, and it had to rise to Rockefeller, Carnegie, and JP Morgan levels before it became a sufficiently large problem to become a political priority for the parties and voters.

Some people think we have similar concerns around concentrated firms, but the mechanisms of concentration are far different from those addressed by existing legislation. For example, Google didn’t gain 90% market share by buying up 20 smaller search engines. Unlike Google, which gained its share organically, Rockefeller built his monopoly by acquiring smaller competitors. What would it even mean to reverse this for Google search? Currently, regulators are proposing splitting out Chrome and maybe requiring Google to license some intermediate search data, but that won’t eliminate Google’s dominance.

Moreover, past political actions did nothing for wealth concentration. Rockefeller's net worth increased considerably following the breakup of Standard Oil because the whole was worth less than the sum of its parts. (I’ve heard private equity folks joke that this was the greatest breakup/carve-out deal of all time.) For that, we can thank the Great Depression, WWII, and the resulting restructuring of the socio-political-economic structure. That was extremely painful for everyone, least of all the robber barons, so I’m certainly not hoping for a comparable solution.

category: Silicon Valley's Tech Hiring and Economic Shifts

title: Friday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Just a consideration from a techie who worked in the identity portion of people-based advertising: is every "like" an actual person? Bots are rampant everywhere, and there's an arms race between bot developers and bot detectors. Commonly created for some types of ad fraud, bots engage in user-like behavior—such as "liking" comments—to evade detection. I doubt Reddit is spending a lot to build or buy bot blockers. They may even have a perverse incentive to inflate engagement numbers.

And I certainly wouldn’t put it past Russia, China, Iran, etc., to build bots to sway discussions. Even domestic actors could do so toward various ends at an annual cost measured in only millions. I don’t want to sound conspiratorial or anything, but if I wanted to take that number seriously, I’d need some details on how they detect and combat bots.

Putting the bots aside: how many accounts are Americans? It’s a global site, and the likes could be 90+% non-American. Even if it’s all Americans, 120k likes could easily be made up of edgy U.S. teens who just think it’s funny because it’s offensive. As a historical comparison point, consider the lyrics from 90s-era Eminem and Dre, both of whom sold millions of records. We all turned out fine despite some of us, including myself, finding the following lyrics hilarious,
https://genius.com/Eminem-im-back-lyrics
> I take seven {kids} from {Columbine}, stand 'em all in line
> Add an AK-47, a revolver, a .9
> A MAC-11 and it oughta solve the problem of mine
> And that's a whole school of bullies shot up all at one time
So we have a multitude of reasons to dismiss this data point in terms of having any meaning.

category: Media and Political Polarization in the Trump Era

title: Saturday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Hiring for software engineers has been a market for lemons since at least 2015. Weak candidates take a while to luck their way into a role and are then let go in a year or two. Meanwhile, strong candidates spend years, even entire careers, at the same firm. When they leave, they find their next role through professional contacts. Hence, even if 75% of CS grads from top schools are solid, interview pipelines have at best 5-10% solid candidates.

I blame the movie "The Social Network" and the increasing desirability of the career path from both a financial and lifestyle perspective for generating such a surplus of marginal engineers. Unfortunately, this coincided with a massive increase in demand for engineers and top-down pressure on managers to fill out headcount. It got truly absurd during the COVID boom, and I assumed we were heading for a crash that would rival the Dot-Com bust because there was no way any of this was financially sustainable.

Thankfully, we're getting a good correction due to the 2022-23 layoffs without catastrophic failure. That and the concerns about AI automating away software engineering are also decreasing interest in the field. Moreover, hiring managers won't feel so desperate to fill out their roles, and teams can instead focus more on getting leverage through vendors and AI coding augmenting tools. For example, an organization with a $5M budget can shift from $4M on staff and $1M on infrastructure/vendors to a $2M/$3M split.

It could still take 5+ years to clear out the current college students' pipeline as well as cycle marginal engineers into other careers. But I am optimistic that by 2030 our field will be in a great place once again.

title: Saturday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I don't know. Just recognize that this stuff has improved rapidly in the last two years and is becoming increasingly useful for my work, both in writing code and in avoiding the need to write code and develop ML models because the problem can be handed directly to a Gen AI model. For example, rather than developing feature engineering code and ML models to classify Substack comments, I just pass the comments to the model with a text prompt describing how I want them classified. It's similar for my professional work.

I reflect on the internet of the mid-90s during my childhood and how impressive it was, as well as how rapidly it changed. Gen AI seems at least an order of magnitude more impressive, so it seems likely there will be a lot of change in the next decade or two.

This doesn't mean it will eliminate software engineering; just that it could be a particularly rapid evolution of the role. Moreover, the same force would affect all other knowledge work, so I'm not sure which career paths are relatively safe. It could even be that the most heavily disrupted fields offer the most upside for individuals who embrace and skillfully apply the tools to remake the function.

title: Wednesday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Has anyone you know personally said this to you in an in-person conversation, or is it just Twitter and TikTok personalities? To me, it’s not surprising that we’ve now invented Fox News-like personalities with other political branding. If anything, it would be surprising if the internet didn’t enable that innovation, along with other increasingly specialized media that appeals to such raw, visceral emotions under various political brands. Who knows, maybe we'll have an SB-themed Tucker Carlson within a year or two?

As a techie, it seems like a continuation of trends that tech analysts like Ben Thompson at Stratechery have been discussing since 2013. Notably, Thompson’s June 2020 article, “Never-Ending Niches”, examines this phenomenon.
https://stratechery.com/2020/never-ending-niches/

The article is outside of his paywall and uses the history of the newspaper industry as a historical comparison. It also includes plenty of helpful figures. I’d recommend skipping the subsequent summary and just reading, or even scanning, the article directly.
But for those who prefer a summary, ChatGPT and I created the following for the SB audience:
• The internet enables endless niches, allowing anyone to become a publisher, which has led to a proliferation of internet personalities catering to hyper-specific audiences.
• Platforms like YouTube, TikTok, and Instagram use algorithms to amplify certain personalities, shifting economic and attention power to these aggregators rather than traditional media gatekeepers.
• Success in this new ecosystem often prioritizes niche appeal (focus) over universal quality, resulting in personalities who excel in specific domains rather than broad-based credibility.
• Unlike traditional media with limited slots and finite resources, the internet’s abundance creates a race for attention, often rewarding controversial or polarizing figures who drive engagement.
• The rise of niche-focused personalities mirrors a societal shift toward smaller, disconnected communities, raising concerns about the loss of common cultural frameworks and shared understanding.

title: End the Medicare For All wars
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: How about we mandate sufficiently transparent accounting from government-funded medical service providers so that we, the tax-paying public, at least know where the money is going and can develop ever more targeted regulations to eliminate rent-seeking?

Moreover, the investment industry would love to know where unreasonably large margins are accumulating (i.e., rent-seeking). Similar to Walmart’s and Amazon’s disruption of insufficiently differentiated independent retailers, we can count on ever more innovation to manage out the waste. Eg, I've heard that the private equity industry is currently attempting to roll up various general practitioners in medical, dental, and vision so that they can get increasingly more leverage over their fixed costs; notably by introducing technology to substitute for inefficiently allocated resources.

category: Evaluating Economic Systems and Policies

title: End the Medicare For All wars
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Yes, but at least taxpayers would know how much is being spent through taxes versus individual contributions for consuming the service. Additionally, academic-like research could use privileged data on consumption patterns to identify cases of moral hazard. This could help establish regulations similar to those for pre-existing conditions. Moreover, instead of fully excluding individuals from treatment, we could simply limit publicly funded options to those deemed sufficiently beneficial based on certain decisions.

These regulations could evolve through political processes to reflect voter preferences. For example, fewer lung cancer treatment options might be offered to smokers than to non-smokers, with these options narrowing further over time. Cutoff dates based on birth year could also be introduced, especially as public awareness grows about the risks of certain lifestyle choices.

category: The Complex Dynamics of Economics and Morality

title: End the Medicare For All wars
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Yes, but private providers are already incentivized to get the accounting correct. Moreover we already have regulations that require sufficiently sophisticated accounting from sufficiently large companies. Eg, GAAP.

We could mandate a sufficiently detailed and rigorous accounting for any medical service paid for by public funds. Moreover, we could also ban price discrimination and thereby ensure we're not getting a subsidy by simply charging private insurance more. I believe that such a subsidy is already alleged.

title: Are place-based policies targeting the wrong distressed areas?
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Double like. It’s understandable that some programs should allocate more funds to high-cost living areas based on their specific aims (e.g., SNAP). Other programs, however, should recognize migration as a key part of addressing the issue—for example, addressing high unemployment among non-college workers.

Yes, many people hold a “pie in the sky” dream that no one should ever have to move for employment and that instead all communities can sustain vibrant economies tailored to their current demographics. But at best, that’s a distraction, and at worst, it misleads individuals in these communities into avoiding the short-term pain of moving by falsely promising future economic opportunities without sufficient justification.

category: The Complex Dynamics of Economics and Morality

title: Are place-based policies targeting the wrong distressed areas?
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: The U.S. has long been a nation of immigrants, including internal migration by people with birthright citizenship. Yes, balancing this with the preservation of communities and personal ties, notably family relationships, is important. However, we should never strive to become like the complacent and unambitious Europeans—communities from which many of our ancestors fled in search of the opportunities offered by the American project.

category: Political Controversies and Governance Challenges

title: Are place-based policies targeting the wrong distressed areas?
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: We should tie the federal mortgage interest deduction to local housing costs as a percentage of income for local, low-income residents, phasing it out in relatively high-cost areas. Subsidizing high-cost-of-living regions disincentivizes growth in housing supply. This approach could be generalized to the SALT deduction, broadening support among affluent individuals who might otherwise oppose new construction but could instead advocate for it.
Maybe the Republicans will do this for us—as they did w/ capping SALT deduction—to “stick it to the libs” in funding tax cuts for the rich?

body.value: Fine if individual people and families choose that given the costs/benefits of their different options. Ie, cool to forgo material standards of living and vocational opportunities to maintain community. But that certainly isn't something that government should be subsidizing and any employment programs targeting these communities should focus on relocation.

category: The Complex Dynamics of Economics and Morality

title: From the veal pen to The Groups
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Agreed. Moreover, I am very hopeful that the continued fragmentation of online spaces will help dilute the harm of these donations by spreading them over a larger number of independent, non-coordinated actors. For example, Musk is smearing crap all over Twitter, yet the exodus isn’t collecting at any Mastodon instance, and even BlueSky is nothing like 2021 Twitter. That should impede the creation of future medium-to-large small-donor movements and, moreover, draw away current funding of existing ones to a plethora of harmless micro movement-esque communities.

To this end, we’re primarily aided by the deemphasis of “social” in social media, with more and more content coming not through algorithmic prioritization of your follows, but instead by scouring the entire network for whatever will be most salient to you in the moment. It’s far harder for large-scale movements to coalesce when everyone is in their own ever-more-personalized echo chamber. And, like everything else, generative AI will transform this like nothing before. There’s will be no need to find the best content on a site when the site can instead directly generate exactly what you crave in the moment.
We just need to muddle through these next few years toward our salvation: the perfect alienation of anyone who could have previously found their way into an online mob.

title: Marc Andreessen on His Intellectual Journey
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Here's a brief AI summarization of the transcript that I found useful in reacquainting myself w/ the interview contents. (w/ markdown formatting in
https://gist.github.com/matthagy/6fb77a6e44f10e5aad9f1e16a8d3fc60
) In general, been experimenting w/ Substack articles summaries because I have way too many subscriptions.
1. Introduction
- Interview with Marc Andreessen about his intellectual evolution from 2016 onwards.
- Discussion centers on understanding global changes, political shifts, and personal reflections.
2. The 2016 Shift
- Marc Andreessen describes 2016 as a pivotal year that disrupted his mental model.
- Key events: Trump’s elections, Charlottesville, George Floyd, January 6th.
- Realized a need to reevaluate understanding of the world and political dynamics.
3. Understanding Political Forces
- Marc's exploration to grasp the left and right spectrum.
- Compared historical left movements (Judaism, Christianity, socialism) against the backdrop of historically right-wing hierarchies.
- Reflects on the intellectual battle between ideas and group interests.
- *Role of intellectuals vs. mass popular sentiment*.
- Example: Communistic writings still influencing modern-day politics.
4. Division Between Left and Right
- Criticism of oversimplifying political motivations as merely “group interests” or “people want stuff”.
- Influence of master vs. slave morality (*Nietzsche's philosophy*).
- The psychological evolution of morality from ancient times to contemporary society.
- **Balance between hierarchy (master morality) and fairness (slave morality)**.
5. The Rise of Wokeness and Its Critiques
- The argument that movements with good intentions can lead to adverse unintended consequences.
- Discussions around the "woke mind virus" as a metaphor for extreme "slave morality".
- Concerns about reaching *pathological egalitarianism*, leading to failures akin to historical communism.
6. The Role of Billionaires and Elites
- Marc's insights into why many billionaires support progressive agendas.
- Influence of elite social circles, invitations to exclusive events, and integration into progressive networks.
- Exceptions like Elon Musk and Larry Page, promoting innovation over traditional philanthropies.
7. Critique of Effective Altruism
- Effective altruism extends Marc's wife's practical philanthropy ideas to a global scale.
- Concerns about over-reliance on utilitarian models leading to playing "God" with societal systems.
- Sam Bankman-Fried as a case study of EA philosophy leading to speculative and unethical practices.
8. Global Governance vs. National Diversity
- Debate over the virtues of diverse national practices vs. centralized global governance.
- Marc supports globalization for technology and trade yet critiques the total imposition of uniform governance.
9. Forming a New Counter-Elite
- Discussion on creating a better elite to replace current oligarchs.
- **Balance of competence and inclusivity**.
- Inspirations from technological pioneers and projects fostering young leaders like Thiel's fellowship.
10. Reasons for Optimism
- Current elite failures create opportunities for change.
- The internet continues to challenge the status quo, despite attempts at control.
- Growing accountability as policies from past decades are proving ineffective.
11. Conclusion
- Emphasis on learning from past mistakes and recognizing the limits of current leadership.
- *Inspiring the need for a balanced, competent, and diverse leadership* to guide future societies.

title: The Origins of Elite Human Capital Institutions and Communities
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Re: “Matthew Yglesias has argued that objective journalism emerged as a product of the business model of mid-twentieth century American newspapers”, for the book you may want to additionally cite and summarize the work of the tech analyst Ben Thompson’s extensive analysis of media business, including how the internet disrupted it. Notably, the following free articles:
* “The Great Unbundling” Jan 2017,
https://stratechery.com/2017/the-great-unbundling/
* “The Local News Business Model”, May 2017,
https://stratechery.com/2017/the-local-news-business-model/
* “Popping the Publishing Bubble”, Sep 2015,
https://stratechery.com/2015/popping-the-publishing-bubble/
* “Never-Ending Niches”, Jun 2020,
https://stratechery.com/2020/never-ending-niches/

Thompson built his reputation on analysis of internet economics; chiefly zero marginal costs and lack of physical distribution limitations. He’s highly respected in tech and these free articles in his newsletter “Stratechery” are a great starting point for anyone who wants to better understand the evolution of the media ecosystem in the internet age. Thompson also extends this to Trump’s disruption of the political process in his May 2016 article, “The Voters Decide”,
https://stratechery.com/2016/the-voters-decide/

And lastly, Thompson pioneered the paid newsletter business model with the launch of his Stratechery newsletter in 2013 (Substacker founders listed his publication as their inspiration). The aforementioned “The Local News Business Model” article has a greater overview of these economics in the section “The Subscription Business Model”. Hence, I think he could be a valuable resource to your readers, and possibly to yourself, in better understanding the evolving economics of paid newsletters.

category: Uncategorized

title: 2024 Was the Year I Didn't Change Much
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Congrats on a great 2024, including the growth in reach and subscribers! I upgraded from a monthly plan to an annual plan to demonstrate my own small financial commitment to your writing. I’d encourage other subscribers to do likewise, as I imagine all writers appreciate the more stable funding of longer-term subscriptions.

I’m particularly looking forward to the future installments of your Elite Human Capital book to better understand and appreciate what distinguishes the cultural and political institutions built by our modern educated classes relative to more instinctual modes of human organization throughout history. I also like this approach of releasing draft chapters one by one because I’m increasingly hesitant to commit to reading entire books when I already have so many engaging newsletters. I hope to see other writers adopt this installment format so that we subscribers can engage with larger topics at a deeper level through our existing subscriptions. Eg, Yglesias did a five-part series on “The Strange Death of Education Reform.” [1]

In terms of topic suggestions, I recently recommended tech analyst Ben Thompson’s work on the evolution of the media business—notably news and opinions—with the internet, in the context of Chapter 2 in EHC concerning the death of mass media. [2] In general, I find Thompson to be particularly insightful on how the internet disrupted the information ecosystem and shattered our shared-consensus reality. He also has a lot to say about the subscription business model because Thompson pioneered the paid newsletter model with the launch of his Stratechery newsletter in 2013 (Substack founders listed his publication as their inspiration).
Thanks for insightful and engaging articles and looking forward to more in 2025!
https://www.slowboring.com/p/why-teacher-evaluation-reforms-flopped

body.value: Facebook make $68.44 of revenue per a user, per a **quarter**, which is $22.81 per a month. See "Trends in Our Monetization by Facebook User Geography" in their most recent 10-K annual report,
https://www.sec.gov/ix?doc=/Archives/edgar/data/1326801/000132680124000012/meta-20231231.htm

> We define ARPU [Average Revenue Per User] as our total revenue in a given geography during a given quarter, divided by the average of the number of MAUs in the geography at the beginning and end of the quarter.

Moreover, that is for the Dec 2023 quarter and they always have relatively higher revenue in that quarter due to the holiday season. There ARPU for the entire 2023 year is $48.85 + $53.53 + $56.11 + $68.44 = $226.93. Which averages out to $18.91 per a month.

title: Predictions for 2025
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: > it would already be getting great scores on PhD subject matter exams and would be much better at coding
OpenAI’s o1 (announced Sept 12 2024), and now o3 (semi-announced Dec 20 2024), are reaching PhD-subject matter expert levels as well as blowing away coding benchmarks.
From o1 announcement,
https://openai.com/index/learning-to-reason-with-llms/

> OpenAI o1 ranks in the 89th percentile on competitive programming questions (Codeforces), places among the top 500 students in the US in a qualifier for the USA Math Olympiad (AIME), and exceeds human PhD-level accuracy on a benchmark of physics, biology, and chemistry problems (GPQA).
o3 doesn’t even yet have a formal announcement. Just the blog post “o3 preview & call for safety researchers”,
https://openai.com/12-days/?day=12
and a storm of tweets from OpenAI researchers and collaborators. Today, Zvi Mowshowitz published a consolidated collections of results and analysis in
https://thezvi.substack.com/p/o3-oh-my
. Here are some highlights:
> Deedy: OpenAI o3 is 2727 on Codeforces which is equivalent to the #175 best human competitive coder on the planet.

> Nat McAleese: Scores are impressive elsewhere, too. 87.7% on the GPQA diamond benchmark surpasses any LLM I am aware of externally (I believe the non-o1 state-of-the-art is Gemini Flash 2 at 62%?), as well as o1’s 78%. An unknown noise ceiling exists, so this may even underestimate o3’s scientific advancements over o1.
> o3 can also perform software engineering, setting a new state of the art on SWE-bench, achieving 71.7%, a substantial improvement over o1.

> Well, on FrontierMath 2024-11-26, o3 improved the state of the art from 2% to 25% accuracy. These are extremely difficult, well-established, held-out math problems. And on ARC, the semi-private test set and public validation set scores are 87.5% (private) and 91.5% (public)

I’ve already found o1 to be overkill for most software engineer problems. Moreover, 4o w/ search is best for anything of a factual nature because I can check its sources. Eg, when I wanted to sanity check a Facebook financial metrics in yesterday’s comments,
https://www.slowboring.com/p/sunday-thread-mailbag-8ce/comment/83612822

So we shouldn’t expect many more improvements for us mere mortals for now. OpenAI and other labs are focused on competing w/ top-tier human experts on math and scientific research problems. Maybe some of that will flow back to helping us peons?

category: Impacts and Implications of AI in Various Domains

title: How to get slightly better at things
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I wouldn’t call Nate’s Substack-advice article “grifty” because there’s no illusion that this is something just anyone can do—i.e., it’s not some get-rich-quick scheme. Maybe it could use an explicit disclaimer to that end—comparable to Yglesias’s caution to aspiring writers in today’s article—but it seems pretty clear to me that Nate is just describing what worked for him, with no pretense that anyone could duplicate his success.

I also agree with your characterization of “Too many small Substacks are paid.” If anything, I think such writers could learn from the career history of Yglesias, Nate, Ezra, and others, all of whom began with years of non-monetized blogging, driven by a compulsion to write and be part of the public conversation. I imagine almost all early-career, aspiring newsletter authors should similarly begin with free blogging on the side. That allows them to hone their craft, build their brand, and verify whether this is something they actually want to do professionally. Worst case, they build up a portfolio of work they can reference when applying for other writing opportunities.

title: New Years Eve Thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: The "felony murder rule" is quite common in the US. From
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felony_murder_rule

> The rule of felony murder is a legal doctrine in some common law jurisdictions that broadens the crime of murder: when someone is killed (regardless of intent to kill) in the commission of a dangerous or enumerated crime (called a felony in some jurisdictions), the offender, and also the offender's accomplices or co-conspirators, may be found guilty of murder.

> The concept of felony murder originates in the rule of transferred intent. In its original form, the malicious intent inherent in the commission of any crime, however trivial, was considered to apply to any consequences of that crime regardless of intent.
> United States
> As of August 2008, 46 states in the United States had a felony murder rule, under which felony murder is generally first-degree murder. In 24 of those states, it is a capital offense.

title: Sunday thread + Mailbag
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Agreed. o3 is looking extremely impressive. Moreover, it and other state-of-the-art models are focusing primarily on PhD-level performance in fields such as math, physics, and medicine, meaning that few of us laypeople can appreciate these recent advances.

GPT4o and Claude 3.5 Sonnet are already sufficient for most knowledge labor and the remaining work is in adapting software, workflows, roles, and organizations to better leverage these tools. That could take a decade or two and we'll see the early results in newer companies and institutions that can adopt different job descriptions, processes, and org charts from scratch. Only then will legacy firms go through the painful and error prone reorgs to attempt to adapt and survive.
For anyone looking for an overview of o3, I'd recommend Zvi Mowshowitz Dec 30th 2024 collection of results and analysis,
https://thezvi.substack.com/p/o3-oh-my
. Here are some highlights:
> Deedy: OpenAI o3 is 2727 on Codeforces which is equivalent to the #175 best human competitive coder on the planet.

> Nat McAleese: [o3 scores] 87.7% on the GPQA* diamond benchmark surpasses any LLM I am aware of externally (I believe the non-o1 state-of-the-art is Gemini Flash 2 at 62%?), as well as o1’s 78%. An unknown noise ceiling exists, so this may even underestimate o3’s scientific advancements over o1.

* GPQA (Graduate-Level Google-Proof Q&A) Diamond is a benchmark of rigorously validated, graduate-level multiple-choice questions spanning biology, physics, and chemistry, designed to challenge AI with complex problems that are difficult even for skilled non-experts using unrestricted internet access.
> o3 can also perform software engineering, setting a new state of the art on SWE-bench, achieving 71.7%, a substantial improvement over o1.

> Well, on FrontierMath 2024-11-26, o3 improved the state of the art from 2% to 25% accuracy. These are extremely difficult, well-established, held-out math problems. And on ARC, the semi-private test set and public validation set scores are 87.5% (private) and 91.5% (public)

category: Impacts and Implications of AI in Various Domains

title: Four years later
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: > no reasonable person could look at his situation and conclude that he [Hunter Biden] wasn’t being singled

Unfortunately, I don’t think we can assume voters are sufficiently reasonable in this dimension, or at least that they’re receiving a fair and balanced perspective on the allegations against Hunter Biden. Moreover, while I agree that he’s being singled out, I also believe there’s credible evidence that he’s a criminal who engaged in shady behavior, possibly extending to trading on his family name and connections.

Hence, I’m totally fine with throwing Hunter Biden under the bus to minimize the bad optics of a pardon—doubly so after President Biden already promised not to pardon his son. Reasonable people can certainly disagree on the tradeoffs being weighed here.

Moreover, it almost certainly won’t matter. I doubt that few, if any, voters will condone Trump’s future, more corrupt pardons but would have condemned those actions had it not been for the Hunter Biden pardon. At most, it just gives another excuse to those already converted to the Trump cult.

category: Political Controversies and Governance Challenges

title: Four years later
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Agreed. And I recall reading about how the founders explicitly sought a relatively strong executive following the state-level failures of weak executives created during the Revolutionary War era. It's my understanding that numerous states created weak executives, with a focus on committees and congresses, due to their heightened concerns of tyrannical despots as they rebelled against monarchy. Yet those governments were pathologically ineffective, which created their own problems. Striking a balance between effectiveness and accountability is quite hard.

title: Skilled immigration is good
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I strongly second this as another software engineer. Software is all about leveraging upfront fixed costs and near-zero marginal costs at scale. Nothing gives an engineer more leverage than other software—both in multiplying the productivity of upfront development time and in minimizing operational costs. This includes cloud services and DevTools SaaS, as well as open-source, high-level programming languages and libraries. The only reason we engineers can earn so much in a financially sustainable way is that we have incredibly powerful tools developed by other engineers.

That includes other engineers at our employer; sometimes just our own past work. And when you’re “in the trenches,” you want the strongest current and past colleagues you can get. Even if they have a fancier title and a larger comp package than yourself, you desperately want the best tools and existing code you can get.  The incentives also aligned financially—particularly our stock-base comp—in that the more productive we are in aggregate, the better our firm performs.

So software engineers—especially those of us who have worked with colleagues with a diverse range of competencies throughout our careers and can viscerally appreciate strong teammates—should be the strongest advocates for more software engineer immigrants.

category: Silicon Valley's Tech Hiring and Economic Shifts

title: Skilled immigration is good
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: > with middling Python proficiency hired by our tech industry before we even think of hiring people from overseas

Plenty of people with just "middling Python proficiency" cannot be employed in tech. Attempting to would just burden their colleagues. It's unfortunate these individuals weren't given feedback early in their education so that could either shape up or change majors. Yet now they need to listen to market signals and either do sufficient independent study to become employable or they need to change occupations.

Avoiding these education/aptitude mismatches going forward is going to involve some serious reforms to higher education. Notably we need to dissolve the current “customer is always right” model that discourages flunking students out. Degree-granting institutions (and even bootcamps) need to feel some pain when their graduates fail to succeed in the labor market such that they’re incentivized to only grant credentials to students that have demonstrated sufficient aptitude and work habits to succeed in their field of study.

category: Silicon Valley's Tech Hiring and Economic Shifts

title: Skilled immigration is good
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I largely agree, but that belief is no more useful than, "most people can be trained to run a marathon." Even if there is some truth at a physiological level, it doesn't change the fact that very few people are going to attempt training or are going to quickly give up. Whatever it is that gets some people to diligently go through the actions of training to the point where they can do a marathon—or program in an economically useful fashion—we don’t know how to replicate it. Likely some mix of innate strengths (and weakness), life experience, and happenstance.

category: Education, Inequality, and Policy Debates

title: Skilled immigration is good
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Agreed as another engineer on the hiring side. Even before the AI generated slop, there was a general pray-and-spray approach that candidates took to applying. Eg, just mass applying to every single LinkedIn "easy apply" software job listing. That puts the impetus on the hiring team to filter and prioritize applications. Some of the filtered out candidates may even be a good fit, but with just a generic LinkedIn profile/resume designed for mass applying, we can't tell.

Asking candidates to meet in person does sound like a decent filter for serious candidates. I'm thinking anything that adds in some friction such that candidates have to decide whether this is a role that is a sufficiently strong fit for their experience/interests to be worth their time explore is helpful towards that end. Similarly, we on the hiring side need to provide a clear, concise, and specific description of the role and company in order for candidates to make that determination.

Ultimately hoping the whole engineering employment market structure will evolve from the current broken equilibria. For too long it seems like both sides of the market have been incentivized to embellish, and at times cheat and lie, with the assumption that getting to signed offer is all that matters. For the candidates, a lot of that is motivated by the reluctance of firms to fire for insufficient performance and the slow pace at which those decisions are made. Probably something similar on the firms side where it can be assumed hires will stick around for a year or two and even a demotivated employee is acceptable relative to keeping head count open.

category: Silicon Valley's Tech Hiring and Economic Shifts

title: The '90s weren't that great
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: The subscription vs. pay-per-view debate has been discussed numerous times in SB comment sections. To provide the argument for subscriptions, I'm going to lazily reuse a past comment of mine from Dec 2023,
https://www.slowboring.com/p/another-brutal-year-for-the-media/comment/45242472

Pay-per-view is a bad business model. Publishers don’t want sporadic purchases, but instead the more consistent revenue from subscriptions (and ads). That entails creating a product that is a regular, consistent, novel point of view. Select free articles, as well as publicly on other venues like twitter can convince potential subscribers to consider the product. Customers need to be compelled to commit to a paid subscription.

The tech analyst Ben Thompson has written extensively on the subscription business model for news and opinion publications. He has first hand experience as he’s been running an amazing paid newsletter since 2013. (Substack founders cited him as their inspiration). Notably, see his 2017 article, “The Local News Business Model” [1]

> It is very important to clearly define what a subscriptions means. First, it’s not a donation: it is asking a customer to pay money for a product. What, then, is the product? It is not, in fact, any one article (a point that is missed by the misguided focus on micro-transactions). Rather, a subscriber is paying for the regular delivery of well-defined value.
> Each of those words is meaningful:
> Paying: A subscription is an ongoing commitment to the production of content, not a one-off payment for one piece of content that catches the eye.
> Regular Delivery: A subscriber does not need to depend on the random discovery of content; said content can be delivered to the subscriber directly, whether that be email, a bookmark, or an app.
> Well-defined Value: A subscriber needs to know what they are paying for, and it needs to be worth it.

He has a lot of free articles that cover news and more generally the media industry, particularly how the internet disrupted it. If you find this topic interesting, I bet that you’ll find reading a few convinces you to commit to a paid subscription for $120/yr.
https://stratechery.com/2017/the-local-news-business-model/

title: The '90s weren't that great
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I don't get the impression that Lewis intended this as a dismissal of critical thinking about technology, but instead the general pattern we've seen across numerous technology adoption cycles. Just because older people are predisposed to being uncomfortable with technology developed in their adulthood doesn't mean they're wrong in any specific criticism. Yet we should expect some degree of discomfort from older cohorts relative to younger users, and moreover we should expect the younger cohorts to more easily accept these technologies as the "natural state of things".

In terms of working through any specific criticism the devil is always in the details. Are the youth foolishly adopting a negative technology or cultural change because they don't know any better? Or are the older generations yet again failing to get with the times? It'll certainly come down the nuances of the critique as well as the possibility for an alternative.

As discussed in this article, adults would struggle to go without a smartphones despite the fact that was totally natural to not have a cell phone in the 90's. Just because there are some downsides to smartphones doesn't mean there's a straightforward alternative for most people. Although I do think we are increasingly learning the value of keeping phones and other digital distractions out of the classrooms.

category: Silicon Valley's Tech Hiring and Economic Shifts

title: The '90s weren't that great
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Yes, although I remember my parents complaining about the ever-changing mediums throughout their lives: records → cassettes → CDs → MP3s. In particular, they felt they should’ve been able to trade in the old medium for the new one and only pay the physical manufacturing cost. Similarly, they bet on Betamax over VHS initially, so we still had that old piece of hardware and some movies in the early ’90s.

By contrast, I was an early adopter of Amazon Video on Demand and still have digital purchases from the early 2010s. I happily ditched my old DVDs when moving cross-country in 2013, figuring I could always digitally buy or rent as needed. I haven’t regretted that decision and am glad I’m no longer lugging around DVDs and an antiquated disk reader, analogous to my parents’ old Betamax.

category: Evolving Media Models in the Digital Age

title: Thursday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: It’s easy for me to dismiss Zuck’s recent change in moderation policies as just him following political currents, or even showing fealty to Trump. Moreover, the same could be said about his embrace of misinformation policing in the aftermath of the 2016 election, where Facebook and Twitter “fake news” were blamed for the results.*

Yet I will say his recent statement is quite candid and direct, and it definitely represents a better direction for Facebook and Instagram in the long term. I’d recommend watching his recent short video message to appreciate this,
https://www.instagram.com/p/DEhf2uTJUs0/
. Transcript,
https://x.com/justlikethepoet/status/1876612805685583958
Notably, the following excerpt stands out:

> After Trump first got elected in 2016, the legacy media wrote nonstop about how misinformation was a threat to democracy. We tried in good faith to address those concerns without becoming the arbiters of truth, but the fact checkers have just been too politically biased and have destroyed more trust than they've created, especially in the US.

Zuck does seem genuinely pissed that his attempt to address misinformation concerns raised by critics earned them zero credit—if anything, it only led to further attacks on him and Facebook—while simultaneously enraging the other half of the political spectrum, who felt they were “being censored.” (As if anyone has a natural right to broadcast on someone else’s platform.) This was a lose-lose proposition, and it’s good to see Zuck abandoning the futile mission of being the arbiters of truth and acceptable opinions.

* Here’s an excellent refutation of the belief that internet fake news was to blame for 2016—at most, it’s a distracting narrative that deflects from conventional media’s culpability, including the NYT’s extensive coverage of Hillary’s email security lapses:
https://stratechery.com/2020/twitter-responsibility-and-accountability/

category: Media and Political Polarization in the Trump Era

title: Thursday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: There’s still a significant amount of political content on Meta properties [1], and it’s a testament to their filtering and prioritization algorithms that little of it makes its way into your feed, thereby satisfying your personal preferences. Meta explicitly attempted to deprioritize such content globally on Instagram and Threads, but the later platform’s failure to succeed is calling that decision into question, particularly as BlueSky has managed to capitalize on the user exodus from Twitter.

The main issue is that Meta shouldn’t be in the editorialization business, especially when it comes to policing the nebulous and ever-expanding concept of misinformation. Their futile attempts to do so failed to satisfy proponents of misinformation management while simultaneously enraging users who felt they were being censored. The community notes model works better because it simply provides additional context without influencing the filtering and prioritization of content.

I continue to believe that an even better model for social media algorithms would give users agency in shaping their feeds, including shared responsibility for the outcomes they criticize. A simple model could allow users to choose among multiple algorithms, including a generic, neutral option as well as third-party-provided filtering and prioritization methods—for example, algorithmic feeds shaped by NYT, Fox News, and others. This way, user frustration with the results would be directed primarily at these third parties, allowing Meta to focus on being a neutral platform provider.

There was some outside interest in such an approach when Musk took over Twitter, as it would have allowed him to lean into the “free speech” angle without owning the consequences. I elaborated on this concept—riffing on a Stratechery article—in a Nov 2022 comment [2], for those curious to explore that approach further. Obviously, Musk went in a different direction. I believe BlueSky also aspires to a similar “choose your own algorithm” model, though they currently implement some degree of platform-level moderation, which has been drawing attention. I suspect their moderation will remain relatively stringent compared to the ideal of only censoring content that is illegal in a country-specific manner.
Nonetheless, I still hope that some platforms will eventually offer such user choice, and I continue to experiment with similar approaches for shaping my own consumption of Substack comments.
https://about.fb.com/news/2024/12/2024-global-elections-meta-platforms/
https://www.slowboring.com/p/elon-musk-needs-to-make-twitter-better/comment/10137853

category: Financial and Strategic Challenges for Substack and Social Media Platforms

title: A frozen mailbag
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I question whether it would have been worthwhile for U.S. consumers to pay higher prices to minimize the disruptions of a once-in-a-century pandemic. Overall, things weren’t that bad, and I doubt even now there’s much political will for higher prices in exchange for anything, given voters’ recent anger over relatively mild inflation.

Moreover, I’m guessing U.S. supply chains will become increasingly robust as we reshore more manufacturing for economic reasons alone, given the accelerating progress in automation. Eg, I vaguely recall some discussion about clothing manufacturing research and startups at Georgia Tech circa 2010, and numerous critics thinking it was ridiculous given the low margins in apparel. Yet advocates pointed out the transportation costs, particularly with Georgia and other parts of the U.S. still growing and exporting cotton. Furthermore, eventually, machines will outcompete humans even in the lowest labor-cost countries. Here’s a 2017 article on such “sewbots” [1], and I’m guessing the “Georgia Tech Manufacturing Institute” [2] is where the associated research is being conducted.

So, I’m increasingly confident the U.S. will have more robust domestic manufacturing for numerous goods due to our multitude of natural resources. However, I doubt this will be celebrated by many proponents of U.S. manufacturing because it will resemble semiconductor manufacturing, where even the lowest-level roles require at least a master’s degree from an elite institution.
https://www.fastcompany.com/40454692/this-t-shirt-sewing-robot-could-radically-shift-the-apparel-industry
https://research.gatech.edu/manufacturing/flexible-automation

title: Saturday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I found a fascinating and rather discomforting Bloomberg article on the female analog of cryptocurrency/memestock speculation and sports gambling, labeled “a feminine financial nihilism,” in How ‘Disaster Girls’ Are Cashing in on the Digital Economy [1]. It had me reflecting on the recent SB article “Men and women are different” within this particularly absurd context of financial nihilism, where there are now apparently both male- and female-coded variants.

The Bloomberg article focuses on “Trad Influencers” and “Disaster Girl” entrepreneurs who capitalize on these female-themed trends by shilling both digital and physical goods and services. For example, “finfluencers selling crystals as the solution to financial insolvency” and a woman described as “a kind of virtual puppet, animated by virtual tokens sent by viewers.” Surprisingly, the article didn’t mention OnlyFans or other digital sex work but did highlight related communities where women discuss strategies for finding a male provider or a straight up sugar daddy. Overall, this realm strikes me as quite dystopian and disappointing, especially from my perspective as an elderly millennial.

I wish the article had focused less on the few who managed to profit from these trends and more on the larger number of young women wasting time and money—analogous to male financial nihilists. For instance, what type of person buys crystals to address financial issues? Do we have female equivalents to male degenerate sports gamblers? I imagine there’s a lot of collateral damage from, “On Sugar Bowl Reddit forums, where those seeking a transactional relationship congregate to discuss the terms of an exchange.”
[1] [gift link, hence the messy-ness]

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-01-10/tradwife-delulu-girl-npc-how-women-are-cashing-in-on-social-media?accessToken=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJzb3VyY2UiOiJTdWJzY3JpYmVyR2lmdGVkQXJ0aWNsZSIsImlhdCI6MTczNjYyMTI4NCwiZXhwIjoxNzM3MjI2MDg0LCJhcnRpY2xlSWQiOiJTUFZJU0JUMEcxS1cwMCIsImJjb25uZWN0SWQiOiJBRTM0NDZCMTRFMDQ0QzBCQkE0NTRFMTNDQUNFQzk4NiJ9.x2K6vuB9E3JJ2B_qkzDOlevuPwDMC6dmuq-BjzDG6jY

title: Saturday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Agreed. I think there’s a general theme of Democratic politicians prioritizing counterproductive issues to appease a small but loud constituency (i.e., “The Groups”). In the case of tech, particularly social media, I imagine journalists played a role due to their visceral despair over how these tech firms “disrupted” the news business and media industries at large. Some of it was likely just general “challenging power.”

Regardless, it was a mistake because, as you’ve pointed out, we didn’t really achieve anything significant here. At most, we may have slowed some mergers and acquisitions with Lina Khan at the FTC. Our Democratic leaders should reflect on this strategy and the value of sometimes telling certain constituencies to “pound sand.” They represent so few people directly, and even their broader cultural power is waning—particularly with Musk and now Zuck reorienting their social media platforms.

category: Challenges and Strategies in American Political Messaging

title: Sunday thread + Mailbag
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Continuing off of your recent SB article, “Men and women are different”, what do you make of “Zuckerberg Says Most Companies Need More ‘Masculine Energy’” as reported by Bloomberg. [1]
From a transcript, [2] I believe this refers to the following segment starting around 1:28 on YouTube. [3]

> It's kind of just what I was saying before. I think, for me, it's just I think a lot of the corporate world is pretty culturally neutered. And I just think having, you know, I grew up, I have three sisters, no brothers. I have three daughters, no sons. So I'm like surrounded by girls and women like my whole life. And it's like, so I think, I don't know, there's something, the kind of masculine energy I think is good.

> And obviously, you know, society has plenty of that, but I think corporate culture was really like trying to get away from it. And I do think that there's just something, it's like, I don't know, all these forms of energy are good. And I think having a culture that like celebrates the aggression a bit more has its own merits that are really positive. And that has been kind of a positive experience for me. Just having a thing that I can just do with my guy friends and we just beat each other a bit, it's good. It is good. I agree. I don't know, it's good. It is good. I agree. I don't know. It's good.

> I do think that if you're a woman going into a company, it probably feels like it's too masculine. It's like there isn't enough of the energy that you may naturally have, and it probably feels like there are all these things that are set up that are biased against you, and that's not good either, because you want women to be able to succeed and have companies that can unlock all the value from having great people, no matter what their background or gender. I think these things can always go a little far.

> And I think it's one thing to say we want to be welcoming and make a good environment for everyone, and I think it's another to basically say that masculinity is bad. And I just think we kind of swung culturally to that part of the spectrum, where it's all like, OK, masculinity is toxic. We have to get rid of it completely. It's like, no. Both of these things are good. It's like you want feminine energy.

The transcript is slightly off and I lightly modified it to remove Rogan’s small comments in the middle and repeated words while Zuck stutters a bit on this complex topic. As a Rogan podcast, it’s all over the place and rather rambly, so text likely isn’t the best way to communicate his vibe here. Moreover, they address this topic in other parts, including something about us no longer needing hunting to get meat and us lacking that outlet to appreciate male-coded behavior. I worked through the whole podcast and I agree with the Bloomberg reporting that this is one of the vibes he’s communicating in addition to complaining about the Biden administration pressuring them to censor more content, particularly around Covid.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-01-10/mark-zuckerberg-slams-biden-administration-on-joe-rogan-s-podcast
https://podscripts.co/podcasts/the-joe-rogan-experience/2255-mark-zuckerberg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7k1ehaE0bdU&t=5323s

body.value: Ah, it's podcast, and The Joe Rogan Show at that. Just a long form, meandering conversations, filling hours. Random space fillers like those will come out while someone works out their response.

Now we could question why such a format is so popular to attract leading CEOs and politicians. Maybe that in someways feels more authentic that a well-rehearsed speech?

title: Don't blame Joe Manchin for child poverty
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Agreed. In retrospect, I find it rather surprising that similar views were shared by some of the working-class people I met in my youth through the world-expanding experience of working minimum-wage jobs. Yet I know, at the time, the “enabling logic” they presented seemed reasonable enough to me, and even now, I don’t think I could convincingly argue them out of such a position when they had firsthand experience they felt supported their “tough love” stance.

It’s understandable why Manchin could credibly believe this and why we should’ve taken his position seriously, rather than quickly dismissing it with the assumption he was just looking out for the wealthy—particularly if many potential beneficiaries and their social groups may feel similarly.

category: Uncategorized

title: Don't blame Joe Manchin for child poverty
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: > making votes based on actual evidence

I imagine we could find at least one position, if not a vote, of every single current and past senator that doesn’t conform to what we, the SB readership, take to be evidence-based policy. Moreover, that certainly doesn’t seem to be what voters value in their elected representatives. At some level, we just have to accept people as they are, including their irrational views, and work with the flawed world as it is if we want to keep making progress toward improving things.

It’s fine if people want to express whatever negative emotions they feel about the failure of the expanded CTC however they please; and it’s also fine if that isn’t grounded in a solid factual understanding either. But at some point, we have to move beyond that and return to a fact-based understanding of what steps we take from where we currently are to make future progress on initiatives like expanding the CTC.

title: Major data revisions are coming

body.value: Agreed! For example, Hoover in the late 1920s, before FDR came in with a mandate to do something different. A lot of the things FDR and others tried didn’t help—some, like the National Recovery Administration and tariffs, likely hurt—but at least he had the political support to try different approaches, and we eventually figured some things out.

Even the experimentation was tough, painful, and extremely controversial (the right saw him as a communist, and the left saw him as a fascist). Yet his bold experimentation allowed us to eventually make some progress.

Again, hopefully, it won’t be as bad as the Great Depression. But I bet, to many people, it will certainly feel that bad. It may even feel like the end of the world for people whose lives are turned upside down. And in a Buddhist sense, they’d certainly be right because they'll become quite different people due to the experience.

body.value: Fair point. From my perspective, I’d say they are behaving as if they feel the implications of Trump 2.0 are a secondary concern for them, even though he is certainly their ideal opposition in some ways.

Moreover, I imagine there is little value in us trying to place ourselves in the minds of such dogmatic fundamentalists. At best, we can recognize that they have a radically different worldview, possibly even a different human experience, and hence we’re unlikely to find any common ground in our beliefs, values, and goals. Therefore, we should focus on minimizing their influence and ultimately alienating them from our communities.

body.value: Well, as a Democrat, allow me to say that I’m finding it increasingly difficult to resist the urge to declare myself a Hanania supporter. You’ve certainly identified something important in this “deep contradiction at the heart of white nationalism,” and it seems useful for fragmenting and eventually scattering this menace that has plagued American society and politics for too long.

Moreover, I also wonder about the implications. What would the Republican Party become without this burden and without their votes? I don’t want to overthink it because it’s quite uncertain how this and other political considerations will evolve.

body.value: > They don’t read and are often religious, though more in a tribal than a truly spiritual sense. The world is frightening to them, and they are hostile to liberals and minorities because they represent uncertainty and change.

I think many people across the political, intellectual, and intelligence spectrum feel that way at times, except perhaps when it comes to reading—though TikTok seems to be influencing young minds everywhere. At best, intelligence can help us cope and guide us through. At worst, it can help justify those feelings and intuitions. It’s interesting to consider what leads some of the most deranged and dangerous intellectuals, on both the right and the left, down this path, while others, hopefully, just bounce around through the turbulence and eventually find their way to smooth gliding.

category: Dynamics of Political Polarization and Media Influence

title: Defeat Racism by Heightening the Contradictions
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: There has always been power in numbers, whether in votes or swords. At times, the numbers can be structured through sufficiently liberal elites—using “liberal” in the most general, old-school definition. Other times, they can be structured through other means, including crude differentiators such as skin color or country of origin. Some even attempt to do so through gender, although that tends to fade within a generation or so. This is why ideas matter and why they must remain sufficiently open to all people while also being resilient to infighting and hostile takeovers.

I doubt we’ll ever find a general solution to this problem. Moreover, the closest attempts seem to come from totalitarian governments, so we may hope such efforts never succeed. Thankfully, every attempt so far has collapsed due to the inherent failures of attempting absolute control. We saw that with the Nazis, the Soviets, and are even seeing cracks in the CCP.

On that last point, the COVID protests that led to the rapid and messy end of lockdowns in China are one example. Additionally, we are seeing something that may be similar in “U.S. TikTokers flock to Xiaohongshu, baffling and bonding with Chinese users.” [1] Ben Thompson has heard reports from his friends in China (he lives in Taiwan) that the regime-biased-algorithms are heavily prioritizing videos of American high school students protesting the TikTok ban to Chinese users, ostentatiously showing how unpopular the American government is with its own people. Thompson made the clever observation that while CCP elites may view this as smart propaganda, they may instead be inadvertently raising awareness of what liberalism offers—the ability to disagree with one’s government. [2]
https://restofworld.org/2025/tiktok-refugees-rednote-xiaohongshu-chinese-users/
[2] Jan 2025 17 - TikTok and Xiaohongshu -
https://dithering.fm/

body.value: Why wouldn’t we want more of those? Particularly if they’re generally increasing the absolute standard of living for almost everyone.

Is the issue some relative status ranking? E.g., that some people would rather be in the top 10% of a horrible world than the bottom 10% of an amazing one. If so, I can’t imagine why any society would want people with that mindset. At most, we can offer everyone an opportunity to keep working on improving their ranking in a generally gradual process. Few, if any, would want rapid changes in relative status, and moreover, you can’t offer that as a system grows in complexity. You basically need quantum-scale precision, like nanometers, for that to work.

title: Tuesday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I largely agree with your sentiments here. Nonetheless, the current approach to homelessness and associated mental health and substance abuse issues is unsustainable in terms of ever growing resource consumption without addressing the issues experienced by other law-abiding residents. People will either vote for alternatives or move away until cities have a fiscal crisis comparable to NYC in the 1970's.

Moreover, this benign neglect is cruel to the afflicted individuals themselves in its own way. In the most extreme cases, some people do require institutionalization to avoid unintentional self harm that compounds to ever increasing physiological and psychological suffering and an early death. Even harsh confinement may be a net positive for some individuals.

And lastly, as Scott Alexander repeatedly reminds us, this is a truly hard problem due the diversity of people's situations and their unique history. Even attempting to write laws or directives quickly results in a mountain of complex, nested legalizes that attempts to simplify people down to knowable states and associated directives. At some level we do have to trust the state employees, including managers and leaders, to use their judgement in changing state action. And any change will result in some negative impacts, for some charitable individuals.

category: Uncategorized

title: What to do with sincere but unpopular beliefs?
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Thank you for another challenging ChatGPT 4o benchmarking example. After 90 seconds it and myself produced the following oddity. Please advise at length on our performance in simplying your views.
Summary (Prioritized and Nested)
1. Core Position
The author refuses to support Kamala Harris, arguing that her “progressive”/anti-police stance is damaging minority and low-income communities rather than helping them.
The blog laments that the Democratic Party once protected vulnerable groups but now (in the author’s view) caters to affluent city-dwellers pushing the narrative that police are systemically racist.
2. Central Arguments Against “Police Are Racist”
1. Flawed Use of Statistics
The article critiques Radley Balko’s studies for being mostly correlational and for not controlling key variables (e.g., crime rates, victim rates, or socioeconomic factors).
It contends that higher Black–White crime rate differences could explain why policing outcomes differ, not necessarily racism.
2. Anecdotes vs. Data
Well-publicized cases like George Floyd and others are considered tragic but do not, in the author’s view, prove systemic racism across all law enforcement.
The blog points out that Black officers have been involved in some of these high-profile incidents, further complicating “racism” as the sole cause.
3. Human Error & Threat Response
The writer emphasizes that humans have an automatic reflex to potential threats, especially in a gun-saturated society.
The blog argues that “better training” alone can’t fully eliminate tragic split-second mistakes.
3. Impact on Policing & Minority Communities
1. Recruitment Crisis
Police departments struggle to hire and retain officers—money alone is not fixing this.
Fewer officers means fewer patrols, which the author believes harms communities with higher crime rates (often minority or low-income).
2. Defunding Consequences
“Defund the Police” is said to have backfired, effectively reducing law enforcement staffing without providing viable alternatives—again, hurting vulnerable neighborhoods the most.
4. Personal Notes
The author references his wife’s long law-enforcement career: she never observed overt racism (e.g., using the n-word) and frequently served minority and low-income communities.
The blog highlights personal anecdotes (e.g., wife’s quick thinking in emergencies) to argue that good policing relies on high-caliber officers capable of swift, accurate threat assessment.
5. Conclusions
The author believes that labeling law enforcement as inherently racist is oversimplified and detrimental, particularly to those most in need of effective policing.
Some tragic outcomes are seen as an unfortunate part of confronting crime, not clear evidence of systemic racism.
The piece ends by warning that continued demonization of police will only shrink the force, raise crime in vulnerable areas, and worsen racial inequalities rather than alleviate them.

title: Trump's Executive Branch Revolution
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I largely agree with these views about the risks of upsetting the current order. Yet the same could said of the presidency of FDR, LBJ, and even Teddy Roosevelt. Their administrations, with various degrees of Congressional and Courts support, did radically change the structure and purview of the federal government. Many of those changes are now seen as positive, but at the time they were considered extreme and destabilizing.

FDR in particular was castigating from the right as embracing Socialism while those on American left branded him a fascist. And many of his administration programs were likely counterproductive, even in the short term. For example, the National Recovery Administration established government mediated cartels to ensure high prices and salaries and thereby fight deflation. Yet the process of structuring specific industries while leaving others to the markets was open at least the appearance of corruption. Moreover, these cartels were highly distortionary and likely harmed economic recoveries. The FDR administration even began to recognize this at the time and quietly wound these down cartels after the NRA was struck down by the courts.

I'm not saying Trump will be celebrated for his bold, novel actions by future generations. Quite the opposite, I imagine he and his administration lack the convictions to work towards outcomes appreciated by the mass majority of voters. Yet that is very much an in-the-moment judgement and history may think differently. Eg, Trump's earlier administration was certainly important in centering our current bipartisan, hawkish stance towards China.

Regardless, our current stance of allowing these issues to grow and compound was unsustainable and at least Trump's team is attempting something. It may come down to future Democratic, or even less-MAGA Republican, administration to develop a reasonable and sustainable approach. So we'll see how this evolves over the coming years.

category: Political Controversies and Governance Challenges

title: Doomscrolling in the age of Trump
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I think the FAFSA is a good example because I my understanding is that all of the relevant law and regulations is already publicly accessible from online sources. Eg, Google returned "20 U.S. Code § 1090 - Free Application for Federal Student Aid",
https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/20/1090
. There are links to assorted ".gov" sites.

Hence, similar to taxes, a motivated and resourceful individual could figure out nearly everything on their own without any support nor even high-level guideance. At most they might need a phone call (or ideally public support forum ticket) to ask for clarification on sufficiently ambiguous cases.

Yet why do we even need such complex procedures and regulations in the first places? So much of this was built incrementally where each additional complication claims to help some charitable group of applicants, yet the sum result in mess for even government experts to apply.

Moreover, there are possibilities for exploitation and the need for auditing. Eg, I recall a fellow college applicant circa 2003 claiming their family was liquidating assets into undocumented forms like cash and precious metals to better qualify for more financial aid. That could've just been an absurd idea their parents joked with (moreover cash withdraws and gold purchases are tracked). Nonetheless, the possibility exists, and I've heard that strategically timed divorces are a known mechanism to enhancing student financial aid.

But why do we even need such a complex system in the first place to determine student aid on a per-a-student basis? Why not just incentivize educational institutions to be financially efficient and reward those that do so with block grants?

category: Uncategorized

title: Doomscrolling in the age of Trump
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: My understanding is that all state action involves some degree of triage and prioritization—for example, when a district attorney or federal prosecutor decides which cases to pursue at the expense of others due to limited resources. While I may not agree with the specific tradeoffs made regarding Trump or Musk, I do agree with the general principle of prioritizing certain laws and regulations over others to fulfill the core function of a government office.

Democrats have embraced procedural fetishism as an excuse for avoiding decisive action and possibly even to justify existing employment and government contracts. Even critics like Ezra and Yglesias still want to operate within the current framework and rely on changes in the law to achieve state capacity. Yet we repeatedly fail to do so—and for good reasons.

I keep coming back to the dynamism and controversy of the FDR presidency. He and his team truly broke with the status quo. While they generally had congressional support, they certainly didn’t rely on proceduralism, and they openly fought with the courts. Many contemporaries were outraged, if not terrified. But that break with the past was necessary to establish a new consensus.

Hopefully, a future Democratic administration can build on the smoldering wreck left by Trump and others—now freed from past constraints. We will be better off with fewer federal workers and fewer union rules constraining future action. Similarly, eliminating federal funding for NGOs that primarily attack Democrats will extricate our leaders from these parasitic organizations.
We don’t need to like what Trump is doing to recognize the opportunity he is creating—if we’re willing to capitalize on it in the future.

body.value: Personally, I couldn’t stand the passive nature of just picking winners and losers, whether in sports or stocks. I’ll gladly lever up on career risk with novel roles and early-stage companies—that feels more within my control to influence the outcome for myself and my team. I’ve also appreciated risk and volatility in various ways throughout my life as a means of enhancing the “being alive” feeling. Similarly, the other risk-seeking individuals I’ve known never seemed to gravitate toward sports gambling or comparable consumption-style betting.

Even across multiple Vegas trips with different friends, at different stages of our lives, I can’t think of anyone whose gambling losses (or winnings at times) dominated the cost of the trip. Like, I would gladly hop into the backseat of a stranger’s car in search of something to liven up the trip—or even invite strangers into our hotel room. But if I was hitting up the ATM, I’d better be confident I wasn’t doing so just to lose more money on craps or blackjack.
Has anyone here struggled with gambling problems in one form or another? Or noticed patterns among people they’ve known with this affliction?

title: Thursday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Yes, and I think it is challenging to square this with these immigrants’ actual desire to be in America despite all the listed drawbacks. Conservatives can easily adopt a zero-sum mentality and focus on protecting citizens’ employment—doubly so given their rejection of economic arguments and empirical evidence that suggests these jobs as existing only due to the flaunting of labor laws and protections.

Liberals, on the other hand, must either accept that framing or take a more paternalistic approach, arguing that it is not in these immigrants’ best interest to allow this, despite their stated desires and actual behavior. The simplest pragmatic argument is that voters don’t like it—whether for faulty economic reasons, respect for the rule of law, xenophobia, racism, etc. I, along with many other SB commentators, can accept that pragmatic argument, but it doesn’t yet seem robust against progressive attacks that we need to “do better.”

category: Challenges and Strategies in American Political Messaging

title: Thursday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: Yes, but all of those restrictions meant to ensure dignified work also create at least the perception of real harm for impacted individuals. When I worked minimum-wage jobs in high school, I sometimes wanted to work more than 40 hours per week. But there was no way McDonald’s was paying overtime to any hourly worker. Management was already exempt, so no one cared if one of them occasionally worked a 20-hour shift as part of a 50-hour week. I once managed to log a 24-hour shift, but I was still hard cut off once I hit 40 later that week.

For me and other teens, this generally just meant less spending money, but for actual adults at the bottom of the economic ladder, it forced them to find second minimum-wage jobs. They understood the constraint, and their complaints about how it complicated their lives were genuine. Thankfully there were other fast food joints on the same highway and they could just walk between locations should they be transport constrained. I doubt they’d appreciate any argument about how they should be investing in their future with education or training—or even just getting some exercise. One woman was literally just working in the kitchen at McDonald’s until the earliest day she could claim Social Security, and we all joined her in celebrating her last day.

I imagine immigrants escaping material poverty and the risks of disease and violence—far beyond anything imaginable in the first world—are never going to be receptive to our paternalistic arguments. At most, they may just see this as another form of corruption and gladly accept any undocumented employment as a way to address their issues. Some of them may even end up featured on Fox News, complaining that the “socialism in America” is comparable to what they fled from—Cuba, Venezuela, CCP China, etc.

category: The Complex Dynamics of Economics and Morality

title: Thursday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I definitely appreciate the challenges of employment law when hiring for fast-growing tech companies—and also as an applicant looking to be hired. I’ve long wanted to use three-month trial periods to address the uncertainty of interviews in assessing aptitude and willingness to do the job. Yet I recognize why HR and legal teams see that as risky. Contract-to-hire can be an option, even structured as an internship, but that introduces its own challenges compared to standard W-2 employment.

As a candidate with increasingly idiosyncratic employment preferences, I’ve attempted to negotiate various bespoke employment contracts, but I have yet to see one actually executed. Larger companies are almost never in a position to create such novel agreements. Even startups find it easier to classify someone as a W-2 employee or, at most, structure a temporary contractor or consultant agreement and then work out the details as the relationship develops.

Part of my financial planning over the next few years involves figuring out what sort of legal vehicle I can create to present myself as a highly legible “service provider” with exceptional flexibility—allowing firms to purchase my services on terms that would never be acceptable for traditional employment. It could eventually prove to be highly lucrative overtime if I gain broad early experience as an “AI enabled X” for various roles that are at least tangential to my existing employment experience.
