title: Mailbag: The payment system endgame
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: > Silicon Valley is so disconnected...

There’s a lot to respond to here, and I’m going to ignore the Musk stuff for now. These are multi-trillion-dollar market cap corporations, and it’s deeply frustrating how easily many people want to dismiss them as lucky fools. So much of their counterintuitive behavior becomes more understandable when we consider the broad historical arc of tech, dating back to semiconductors in the 1950s, if not earlier.

These are highly volatile industries with massive changes to market structure, notably in where value accrues to firms and individuals. Moreover, there is always great uncertainty around how technologies like the internet, social media, streaming, and now generative AI will actually play out. Tech leadership requires a mix of taking high-conviction positions while making rapid adjustments when bets are failing. That can involve drastic changes to their labor force and org structure, as well as numerous product regressions—whether due to failed initiatives or broader shifts in their ecosystem.

Personally, I love the excitement of the volatile and uncertain world of tech—both as a customer, a tech worker, and even as a passive user or observer. But it’s understandable why others find this deeply frustrating, if not discomforting or even terrifying. Many of these individuals would benefit from stepping back from the digital world and focusing more on their lived reality.

Even we adrenaline junkies need to disconnect at times and exit the digital world entirely. Moreover, it helps to have lived through some of these cycles before and to understand the history of earlier tech insanity. The broad trends have happened before and will happen again. The world will survive, some companies will rise, others will fall, and decades from now, this will just be more boring history—possibly comparable to the rollout of productivity software like spreadsheets in the 1980s and ’90s.
(*Edited to remove my ChatGPT spelling and grammar check prefix)

body.value: I and other teens made minimum wage for most of my time there—$5.15/hr, as I just looked up. [1] My last summer in 2004, I earned an extra $0.25/hr, primarily because I often worked the closing shift.

While I’ve personally never had a bad experience as either an employee or a customer of small, independent businesses, they account for all the horror stories I’ve heard from friends. As your example suggests, some of their decisions can be just. But there’s way more variance across owners, either because they’re less aware of federal, state, and local laws—or they simply don’t care. At least corporate management tries to follow the most salient laws, which creates some level of consistency.

I can see why illegal immigrants might also prefer the flexibility and optionality of under-the-table employment. Even just ensuring all their paperwork is in order can be enough to deter them from seeking jobs with rule-abiding firms—not to mention the tax evasion benefits for both sides of the transaction.

title: Thursday thread
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: As an aside, I really liked the management because they actually treated all of us like adults and were direct in explaining why. Yet they were all quite human and could complain with the best of us. For example, I remember spending multiple days deep-cleaning the entire store with our store manager. Her presence was usually sporadic, but around the annual review, all she did was clean every imaginable surface for about 60 hours a week. I was often drafted to help, and we’d clean side by side with minimal conversation—at least after we got our complaining out of the way.

I briefly met the district manager who performed the post-clean inspection. All I remember is that she didn’t wear anything resembling a McDonald’s uniform but instead some kind of business suit and skirt. She also drove a BMW model that stood out from any other I had seen before.

It was a striking contrast to the regional business owners and my family’s tech consulting business. It left an impression on me that I’d now describe as “the benefit of economies of scale” compared to the horrors of owning all the upside and downside. Then again, in retrospect, she could have just been leasing it and had her personal finances leveraged to the hilt.

category: Uncategorized

title: Should Democrats be left-wing economic populists?
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: I largely agree, but even within your listed examples, I think we can find disagreement among self-labeled pragmatists here in the SB comments. Let’s focus simply on “Fix the climate issue without increasing spending.”

Here, the IRA could be framed as accomplishing this because it roughly decreases the deficit over 10 years while primarily being a “fix climate issues” bill. We could easily get into a 100+ comment discussion about the fairness of that framing, and there certainly are nuances, including reconciliation budget math.

So instead, let’s imagine a hypothetical bill designed toward the aim of “Fix the climate issue without increasing spending.” Obviously, SB subscribers would focus on: a) deregulating land use and b) technological improvements. We could even structure this bill as revenue-raising if we add leasing federal land to solar, wind, geothermal, nuclear, and other non-carbon-emitting energy sources—accelerated by our deregulation. Add in natural gas as a carbon-decreasing alternative to coal, and we’re fixing climate change, lowering energy prices, and even raising federal revenue.

Yet what will ultimately matter is how voters receive both our proposed legislation and its ultimate impact. We could easily imagine such a bill being framed as “big government overreach” or a “sellout to massive corporations.” Maybe Joe Rogan is pissed that the pristine view from his hunting lands will now be sullied by power cables.
Hence, I think there is some “connecting to voters” angle that entails not just policy but also language choices, framing, and fighting for eyeballs in an ever more saturated media environment.

category: Uncategorized

title: Should Democrats be left-wing economic populists?
name: Matt Hagy

body.value: But is it really bullshit if we're practicing the popularism discipline of talking about what voters like about our policies and accomplishments? Not everything needs a fair and balanced treatment. Particularly when voters have such limited attention. We could always refer them to a 172-page analysis by Brookings, but we'll be lucky if we capture 30 seconds in their TikTok or Instagram Reels feeds. For that brief glimpse of their eyeballs, we should use it productively.

Moreover, this will increasingly entail truly personalized media with AI generated content (and ads) created for each individual digital media consumer, aligned with their interest at that moment in time. See Meta's Oc 2023 announcement of "Generative AI features for ads coming to all advertisers",
https://www.facebook.com/business/news/generative-ai-features-for-ads-coming-to-all-advertisers
. There's probably something newer, and less publicized, from Meta and all other tech-enabled digital media platforms.
